instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPRTC_G3H: What is PPRTC_G3H? This is a typo of PPVRTC_G3H When you see PPRTC_G3H, assume they meant to type PPVRTC_G3H.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi, I´m working on this board that is staying at .02 A

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.59
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = pulsing 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = Pulsing 3.3

already changed smc and no change...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check for short on all secondary voltages; all big coils, also pages 57 & 58.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: no short to ground, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too... bad sign right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is unstable, when I remove <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.3v. PCH problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> steady voltage?
Is the battery charging?
Tried SMC bypass mode?

Remove <RESISTOR>R7552</RESISTOR> and check if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> still pulses; also check <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> stable, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> when F7000 in place goes to 8.68v and goes down to 8.58v
smc bypass doesn´t work, the board stays at ,010 amps
removed <RESISTOR>R7552</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> still pulsing... <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Test what happens disconnecting LIO flex; keep only power cable connected to LIO board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
Check for short there.

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> steady high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V5_S5</SIGNAL> steady with pulsing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>???
Are you sure?
Post <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.
